As business becomes more global, international traveling is more commonplace. The accommodations businesspeople encounter around the world vary, although many hotels have adopted a Western style and offer their guests a wide range of services, including restaurants, business services, and exercise facilities. Before you travel, take some time to find out what you can expect once you arrive at your destination.

Asia

Although it's usually a good idea to make your hotel arrangements ahead of time, many international airports have hotel reservation desks. When you reserve a room, make sure you understand the different options that are available to you. In Chinese hotels, for example, a single room has a double bed, but a double room has two beds. In Hong Kong, the more expensive hotels have private baths in each room, but many of the moderately price hotels have shared bathrooms. In Indonesia, the traditional washroom contains a large tank of water. Although it may resemble a bathtub or wash basin, you should not climb into this tank. Use the cup provided to scoop out the water you need to use. Throughout Asia, you'll find sit-up toilets and standing showers in the more upscale hotels, but you can expect the more traditional hole-in-the-floor varieties in many of the older or smaller hotels.

Eastern Europe

Throughout Eastern Europe, you may find hotel reservation desks at the airport, although you are more likely to get the hotel information you need--for a small fee--from a tourist office. Most hotels in Eastern Europe don't offer single rooms. People in those countries typically don't travel alone, so they don't expect other travelers to be alone either. You should be prepared to eat breakfast at your hotel. The meal is considered part of your stay, although there usually is an additional charge.

In many Eastern European countries, you will need to turn over your passport and visa when you register into a hotel. You can expect to get them back within 24 hours. In Hungary, you'll get your passport back once the clerk has recorded the necessary information. In Russian hotels, you will receive an identification card showing the hotel's name and your room number. You will need to present the card when you exchange money or if you visit a hotel other than the one where you're staying. The card indicates that you have official accommodations and a legitimate reason for being in the country.

data.value:
When being introduced for the first time, most businessmen around the globe prefer to be addressed as Mr. (or a similar title) plus their surname. In the United States, people often use the first and last names without Mr. or a title: "Steve Lopez, I'd like you to meet Tim Hogan." This indicates that it is appropriate to use first names, even at the beginning of a relationship. In most Latin American countries, titles such as doctor or professor are preferred, and a formal introduction includes two surnames: first the father's, then the mother's. (In Brazil, the mother's surname comes first.) However, in most everyday interactions, it is common to address men directly using just their father's surname.

In most Asian countries, names are listed in a different order than they are in the Western world. The family name typically comes first, often followed by a title. Proper pronunciation is extremely important, so repeat the name of your new acquaintance to be sure you're pronouncing it correctly.

The Indonesian custom of introduction is one of the most formal in the world. It is important to recognize and respect the preferred greeting sequence: Bapak (Mr.); academic title, if any; title of nobility, if any; given and family name; business title.

For example, a formal introduction for a male executive with the given name Juanda and the family name Kusumaatmaja, could contain all of these elements: Bapak Doctor His Excellency Juanda Kusumaatmaja, Chief Accountant.

When business colleagues or clients visit your country, their expectations about hospitality will vary, depending on the customs in their home countries. To make sure that you show your visitors the appropriate respect and courtesy, it is best to raise your standard of hospitality to the highest possible level.

It is fairly safe to assume that many visitors will expect an official greeting at the airport as well as assistance in finding and settling into their hotel. Here are some specific suggestions for making your visitors feel welcome as soon as they arrive in your country.

  • Have a representative from your company meet the airplane and personally handle the luggage. Ideally, the representative should be fluent in the visitor's language.
  • Make hotel reservations for your guests and confirm their reservations before
    they arrive.
  • Meet with the hotel staff to alert them to any special needs your guests might have (dietary restrictions, medical problems, and so on).
  • Have flowers, fruit, candy, and perhaps tea or coffee from your visitors' home country in their rooms prior to arrival.
  • Accompany your guests to their rooms and help them get acquainted with the
    hotel's services.
  • Arrange for a copy of their hometown newspaper to be delivered each morning.
  • Allow for plenty of rest time before the first scheduled meeting. Your visitors will likely be suffering from jet lag.
  • Give your guests a list of necessary phone numbers and a written itinerary for their visit. Give them whatever information they may need to find their way around
    the city.
  • Offer to assist them with arranging a wake-up call.
